div.head: Multiple Versions of a Text
div.p: In most cases, the main text of an edition will uniform, even though it may be composed of readings from multiple sources representing different branches of a textual tradition. In cases where there is more than one version of the text, and those versions cannot be reduced to variant readings in the critical apparatus, it may be desirable to represent multiple versions in the body of the text.

For example, there are two versions of Servius' commentary on Vergil, commonly referred to as "Servius" and "Servius Auctus." Editors and publishers of print editions have used typographical conventions and page layout to signify where the two versions differ from each other. The following passage from the so-called "Harvard Servius" demonstrates the difficulties:

Reading from the top of the page, the first lines present commentary on Verg. Aen. 3.8 from both Servius Auctus (left) and Servius (right). The two have the same text beginning with vix mox, ut (I 34). They diverge again. At the comment on Aen. 3.9, the vertical line indicates that the comment is found only in Servius Auctus. The critical apparatus presents the entries for Servius Auctus first, then the entries for Servius.

The same issues confront the editor of a digital edition, but those issues are handled not with typographical conventions, but with semantic encoding. Similar conventions might be used to format the text for screens or the printed page, but the encoding provides the foundation for that work.
